description: Navigating Python docs, reading function signatures, help(), and finding what you need

cards.front: Which section of docs.python.org will you use most?
cards.back:
The Library Reference — it documents every module in the standard library.

Other sections:
- Tutorial: learning a topic for the first time
- Language Reference: how syntax works
- HOWTOs: practical guides
- FAQ: common questions

Bookmark the Library Reference.

cards.front: How do you read a function signature like str.split(sep=None, maxsplit=-1)?
cards.back:
str — the type this method belongs to
.split — the method name
sep=None — first param, defaults to None (split on whitespace)
maxsplit=-1 — second param, defaults to -1 (no limit)

"hello world".split()        # ["hello", "world"]
"a-b-c".split("-")          # ["a", "b", "c"]
"a-b-c".split("-", 1)       # ["a", "b-c"]

cards.front: How do you use help() in the Python REPL?
cards.back:
help(str.split)   # help on a specific method
help(json)        # help on a module
help(list)        # help on a type
dir(str)          # list all methods on str

help() shows the docstring — the same text as the official docs, right in your terminal.

cards.front: What do common type annotations in docs mean?
cards.back:
str — a string
int — an integer
bool — True or False
None — no value returned
list[str] — list of strings
dict[str, int] — dict with string keys, int values
str | None — a string or None
Iterable[int] — anything yielding ints
Callable[[int], str] — function taking int, returning str

cards.front: What are 4 strategies for finding what you need in the docs?
cards.back:
1. Search docs.python.org — use the search bar
2. Google "python" + your question
3. Module Index — alphabetical list of all standard library modules
4. Start from what you know:
   s = "hello"
   dir(s)           # list all methods
   help(s.replace)  # read about one

cards.front: What common mistake do beginners make with documentation?
cards.back:
Only reading tutorials, never the reference.

Tutorials teach concepts but are incomplete.
The reference docs are the authoritative, complete source.

Also: skipping the Parameters section (it tells you what each argument does, types, and defaults) and the Raises section (what errors to handle).

cards.front: Where do you find docs for third-party packages?
cards.back:
Third-party packages have their own doc sites:

requests — docs.python-requests.org
Flask — flask.palletsprojects.com
FastAPI — fastapi.tiangolo.com
pytest — docs.pytest.org
pandas — pandas.pydata.org

When docs are lacking, check the project's GitHub README and examples/.

cards.front: What does the * in a function signature mean?
cards.back:
Everything after * is keyword-only — must be passed by name.

json.loads(s: str | bytes, *, cls=None, ...)

The * means cls, and everything after, cannot be positional.

You must write: json.loads(text, cls=MyDecoder)
Not: json.loads(text, MyDecoder)
